headline: Fareed Zakaria GPS
subHeadline: America First, A Fareed Zakaria Special. Aired 10-11a ET

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Reagan made a passionate plea to his fellow Americans that day, to give meaning to those heroes' sacrifice by never turning their back on the world ever again.

utterances.speaker: REAGAN
utterances.sentences: We in America have learned bitter lessons from two world wars. It is better to be here ready to protect the peace than to take blind shelter across the sea.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: America had been protecting the peace with powerful alliances for decades.

utterances.speaker: REAGAN
utterances.sentences: We've learned that isolationism never was and never will be an acceptable response to tyrannical governments with an expansionist intent.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Reagan was expressing a hallowed American ideal, a bipartisan value shared by every president since World War II.DONALD TRUMP, 45TH PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: From this day forward, it's going to be only America First.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Until recently. This is what today's Republican Party sounds like.REP. MARJORIE TAYLOR GREENE (R-GA): My amendment would direct the president withdraw from NATO. SEN. J.D. VANCE (R-OH): NATO has for decades sucked on the teeth of the American taxpayer. ZAKARIA: This is how it talks about longtime allies.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: In France, they have all sorts of problems. Germany is a disaster.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And this is what it thinks about the world.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Americanism, not globalism will be our credo.We've been talking about this for a long time. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: As president, Donald Trump walked away from more international deals than any other president in American history.

utterances.speaker: JOHN KERRY, FORMER SECRETARY OF STATE
utterances.sentences: This moment has been a long time coming.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: From the Iran nuclear deal.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The Iran deal is defective.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: To climate change.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I was elected to represent the citizens of Pittsburgh, not Paris.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: To trade.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We're going to keep out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And according to his own National Security adviser, John Bolton --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The 12 nations undertake the common security.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- he threatened to pull out of the best deal America ever made.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: They were sworn to stand together against aggression.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The NATO alliance. It tore down a wall.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The red flag of the failed Soviet Union at last came down.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Defeated an empire.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Sea, land and air coordination.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And still defends almost one billion people from those hungry for conquest.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: NATO is obsolete. It's old, it's fat, it's sloppy.

utterances.speaker: CHRISTOPHER MCKNIGHT NICHOLS, THE ONE STATE UNIVERSITY
utterances.sentences: That great rule, a kind of policy bedrock of neutrality, was the touch point for American policymakers.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Washington's warning made perfect sense for a young, weak republic and its fragile experiment in democracy. Alliances could lead to war and war could lead to invasion, as well as dangerous division, and even tyranny on the home front.

utterances.speaker: PERRY
utterances.sentences: The tyranny of a standing army and the kind of general who might be governing it.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: America's wisest course would be to enjoy the protection of its massive moats, the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans. After all, the nation has a hemisphere to itself, Thomas Jefferson noted.WILLIAM I. HITCHCOCK, AUTHOR, "THE AGE OF EISENHOWER": America is going to prosper by neutrality, by trade, and by internal development.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But while America steered clear of Europe, it expanded aggressively in its own backyard. Building an empire at home free from power politics abroad. It doubled its size with the Louisiana purchase and captured much of the West in the Mexican war. That's not quite isolationism.Manifest destiny was America's creed in its own hemisphere. A belief that God had ordained its conquest of a continent.

utterances.speaker: HITCHCOCK
utterances.sentences: The transplanting of indigenous people's seizing of their land, and what many people call a genocide against indigenous Americans.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Avoiding entanglements with the rest of the world turned a weak republic into a continental powerhouse. (Voice-over)by the late 1800s. Immigrants seeking freedom and fortune flock to its shores, and a nation now brimming with confidence was becoming a great power. In 1913 --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Wilson was nominated and easily defeated a split Republican ticket.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Woodrow Wilson became president.

utterances.speaker: PERRY
utterances.sentences: Woodrow Wilson is a complex character.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: He began with a declaration that he would stick to the core principles of Washington and Jefferson, that he had no intent to intervene abroad.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Wilson's main focus was his historic domestic agenda including massive labor reforms, anti-trust measures, and other progressive achievements."It would be the irony of fate if my administration had to deal chiefly with foreign affairs," he said. Fate intervened with World War I. Wilson was determined to keep America out of the war having witnessed the horrors of America's civil war as a child. He won reelection on a promise of peace.

utterances.speaker: HITCHCOCK
utterances.sentences: He runs for reelection in 1916, World War I has been going on for two years, on the platform of he kept us out of the war.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Thousands of tons of shipping destroyed weekly.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But then Germany ramped up its aggression with an all-out attack on American ships, sinking three of them.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Congress passes a resolution.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: An agonized president felt he had no choice but to go to war. Now in the conflict, Wilson went all in, vowing to win the war and more importantly win the peace. To create a system that would eliminate the death spiral of European conflicts.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Woodrow Wilson is the pivotal figure I would argue in American foreign policy thought.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Statesmen assembled to draw up the peace treaty.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Germany agreed to peace based on Wilson's 14 points. UNIDENTIFIED MALE

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And he was hailed in Europe as a savior. His bold idea for a new world order was popular. But it proved ahead of its time.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The opposition --

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Back home, the League was met with stiff Republican resistance. So Wilson took his case directly to the American people, barnstorming the country. Without the League, there would be another world war, Wilson warned. His impassioned defense seemed to be winning people over. But suddenly he was felled by a massive stroke, leaving his left side paralyzed. His wife kept it secret and quietly ran the country.The League went down to defeat, and an invalid Wilson finished his term, passing away just three years later. With Woodrow Wilson died any hope of a lasting peace.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Another war not for me. This time America should keep out and I know I will.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Coming up.

utterances.speaker: CHARLES LINDBERGH, AMERICA FIRST COMMITTEE CHAMPION
utterances.sentences: We cannot win this war for England. That is why the America First Committee has been formed.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: America turns inward like never before.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Ruthless aggression and conquest.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And Woodrow Wilson's dark prophecy comes true.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Before Donald Trump made America First a famous catchphrase, another larger-than-life celebrity made it popular in the early 1940s. The famed aviator Charles Lindbergh.(Voice-over): After piloting the first solo nonstop flight across the Atlantic.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The greatest stunt of all.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Charles Lindbergh was an international sensation.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The most idolized man in the world.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: It was 1941, and World War II was raging. The Nazis have taken over most of Europe. But Americans wanted desperately to stay out of the war. 93 percent of them, according to one poll. The America First Committee grew to 800,000 members. And Charles Lindbergh was its champion.

utterances.speaker: LINDBERG
utterances.sentences: We cannot win this war for England, that is why the America First Committee has been formed.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: His biggest opponent, President Franklin Delano Roosevelt. Who knew that if Germany took over Europe, America could be next. It would take his most masterful political performance to ready a nation for war, a war that almost no one in America wanted to get involved with.After the First World War, and over 100,000 dead Americans, the United States had returned to its isolationist roots with a vengeance.

utterances.speaker: MEACHAM
utterances.sentences: There was a sense that we should be fortress America.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Republican presidents signed a strict immigration law and a massive tariff, walling off the country from the rest of the world. Meanwhile, America's military was reduced dramatically.

utterances.speaker: HITCHCOCK
utterances.sentences: America was very, very weak in a smaller army than Romania.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Tariffs deepened the Great Depression in the 1930s, which had left one in four Americans out of a job.

utterances.speaker: MEACHAM
utterances.sentences: It was an existential crisis. And into that moment came Franklin Roosevelt.FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT, 32ND PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I, Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Roosevelt offered a new deal for the country.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: This nation is asking for action, and action now.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A barrage of government programs to get folks working again. But to pass his ambitious domestic agenda and save the country, Roosevelt needed the many isolationists in Congress on his side.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: The challenge for him is keeping them on board on the domestic policy side and not moving too fast on the foreign policy side.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: FDR followed Congress' lead on international matters, signing neutrality acts to prohibit arms sales to any warring country, friend or foe. Roosevelt sent a letter to Adolf Hitler, asking him to respect the sovereignty of 31 countries. The Nazis' response? Hysterical laughter.

utterances.speaker: HITCHCOCK
utterances.sentences: The Nazis laughed at Roosevelt's gesture just as they laughed at American power.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Hitler knew America would do nothing to stop the great German war machine.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: This country should heed the advice of its first president and avoid all foreign entanglements.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Germany invaded Poland in September 1939.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: This nation will remain a neutral nation.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But FDR knew that staying neutral would threaten America's security before long.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: You see FDR slowly maneuvering the U.S. population and policymakers towards intervention in the war.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: I ask this Congress for authority and for fund.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Roosevelt convinced Congress to finally arm the embattled allies with an isolationist argument that they would like.

utterances.speaker: HITCHCOCK
utterances.sentences: The idea was let's build weapons and sell them to Britain and France so they can do the fighting, and Roosevelt said that will keep America out of war.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Guns and munitions of all sorts pour into Britain.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Slowly FDR began winning over the wary American public.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But at the time, many accused FDR of war-mongering and even demanded his impeachment.

utterances.speaker: MEACHAM
utterances.sentences: The struggle between interventionists in the late 1930s and isolationists dwarfed the divisions in the country during the Vietnam era. It was that ferocious.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Roosevelt faced a rebellion in his own cabinet. His secretary of war, Harry Woodring, was a committed pacifist who ignored direct orders from the president that he thought could drag the United States into war.In June 1940, allied forces were routed at Dunkirk. Germany was rolling into Paris. Next on Hitler's list was London. Roosevelt ordered bombers for a desperate Britain, but Woodring refused.

utterances.speaker: PERRY
utterances.sentences: FDR couldn't have an isolationist pacifist as your secretary of war.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Woodring lost his job but not his cause. He walked out of the White House and joined Charles Lindbergh's America First Committee.The committee would be remembered for the antisemites in its ranks. But its support ran well beyond just bigots. Gerald Ford, the poet Robert Frost, and the future Supreme Court justice Potter Stewart were all associated with the group. Isolationism was so popular that it even threatened FDR's reelection in 1940, requiring a somewhat misleading campaign promise.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: Your boys are not going to be sent into any foreign war.

utterances.speaker: PERRY
utterances.sentences: He had to know that wasn't true, but he knew he had to get reelected. So he went ahead and said that.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: FDR won the election. But around 80 percent of Americans still remained opposed to entering the war. All of that would change in a single day.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: December 7th, 1941. A date which will live in infamy.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Japan's deadly attack on Pearl Habor transformed America overnight.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Americans rallied around the flag.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Tens of millions dead. Cities reduced to rubble. An entire continent in ruins. Europe after World War II was a hellscape, decimated by yet another great power conflict that had spiraled out of control.The United States had been drawn into it at a cost of nearly half a million American lives. Yet even after the Second World War, there were many Republicans who still believed in America First, and that the nation's wisest course was to turn inward. It took a World War II hero to inspire an about-face in the party. General Dwight David Eisenhower. He believed that America's enormous sacrifices could not be allowed to have been made in vain. So he campaigned for a fledgling alliance called NATO and led Republicans away from isolationism for the rest of the 20th century. This is the little told story of how a general became a reluctant politician when the world and America needed him most. DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER, 34TH PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: So help me, God.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Before Eisenhower, there had been President Roosevelt, who laid the groundwork for the post-war world. In 1943 he met with Soviet Premier Joseph Stalin outlining his idea for an international organization with, quote, "four policemen." The United States, Britain, China, and the Soviet Union.

utterances.speaker: ROOSEVELT
utterances.sentences: We have learned that we cannot live alone at peace that our own well-being dependent on the well-being of other nations far away.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Tragically Roosevelt would not live to see his dream realized.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The flag flies at half-staff as a grief-stricken nation mourns the death of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, president of the United States.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Just weeks after his death, delegates from 50 nations finalized the charter for FDR's dream, the United Nations.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The charter of a new world is born.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The U.N. was just one prong of a new American-led world order meant to ensure that there would never be a third world war.WILLIAM HITCHCOCK, AUTHOR OF "THE AGE OF EISENHOWER": We accept the principle that American power in the world is a good thing. Isolationism is not the way to peace. Neutrality is not the way to peace. Building the structures of American power with democracies as allies, that's the way to build a peaceful world order.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: There was the Marshall plan, America's multibillion dollar program to rebuild Western Europe.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: American help to supplement European self-help.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to promote peaceful global trade and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization or NATO which would protect its member states from the Soviet Union.CHRISTOPHER MCKNIGHT NICHOLS, AUTHOR OF "PROMISE AND PERIL": Undoubtedly the institutions born out of World War II helped to prevent another major power conflict on the scale and scope of the Second World War.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Both Roosevelt and his successor, Harry Truman, were Democrats, and engagement with the world was their philosophy. On the Republican side, things were murkier.

utterances.speaker: HITCHCOCK
utterances.sentences: There remained what we sometimes call the Old Guard of Republicans who are very critical of this rapid expansion of America's world presence.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Former president Herbert Hoover wanted to end the U.S. military aid to Europe despite the growing Soviet threat. And then there was Ohio Senator Robert Taft. A frontrunner for the 1952 Republican presidential nomination, Taft was a vigorous opponent of the World Bank and the Marshall plan. He also voted against NATO.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: A soldier from Abilene, Kansas, USA.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But there was another big name in the mix for the Republican nomination. General Dwight Eisenhower had a competing vision for America's place in the world. He had led the Allied forces to victory as their supreme commander in Europe. Exhausted from his years in uniform, Eisenhower fantasized about buying a ranch and retiring.DWIGHT EISENHOWER, 34TH PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I intend to have nothing whatsoever to do with partisan politics.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But then, duty came calling again in the form of a request from President Truman. Would Eisenhower be willing to serve as NATO's first military commander?

utterances.speaker: HITCHCOCK
utterances.sentences: Truman needs somebody, some electric personality to really sell the idea of a permanent alliance, which is something America had never done.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The Soviets had taken over Eastern Europe and were trying to extend their control across the continent. Eisenhower took the NATO job.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: An order announcing his assumption of command.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: He made a forceful case for the new alliance to the nation.

utterances.speaker: EISENHOWER
utterances.sentences: If we Americans seized the lead, we will preserve and be worthy of our own past. Our children will dwell in peace. They will dwell in freedom, they will read the history of this decade with tingling pride.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But there was one man Eisenhower was especially eager to convince, the Republican frontrunner for president, Robert Taft.Before the 1952 Republican primary, Eisenhower met with Taft and proposed a deal. He, Eisenhower, would withdraw publicly from consideration for the nomination on one condition, that Taft endorse NATO. But Taft refused.

utterances.speaker: HITCHCOCK
utterances.sentences: He says, I'm not doing it. I've been an isolationist all my life. I believe America should look inward, not outward. I would never say such a thing.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Eisenhower had long been reluctant to enter the political fray but with NATO on the line and public support for his candidacy catching fire, he felt he had no choice.

utterances.speaker: HITCHCOCK
utterances.sentences: If Taft became president, it would be a blow to everything he had done to win World War II, to build NATO. So he's persuaded that to defend internationalism, to defend this new American order, he must run for president.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Chicago becomes the focal point for the nation's eyes as the bitterest Republican convention in 40 years gets underway.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A contested convention followed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Senator Taft was hiding out a fierce battle against the newcomer.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Taft was a formidable foe.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Now cheers by those who like Ike.

utterances.speaker: EISENHOWER
utterances.sentences: You have summoned me to lead a great crusade for freedom in America and freedom in the world.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Those words ushered in a new era.

utterances.speaker: NICHOLS
utterances.sentences: Eisenhower running and winning transformed the Republican Party.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Republican presidents were now ready to take to the world stage in defense of the Western liberal order.

utterances.speaker: BARBARA PERRY, UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA
utterances.sentences: Eisenhower should be given a tremendous amount of credit because he really did smother than the Republican Party the isolationist movement for those many decades.

utterances.speaker: RONALD REAGAN
utterances.sentences: Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: In 1989, the Berlin wall fell, and soon so did the Soviet Union.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: In Moscow the hammer and sickle is lord for the last time.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Patrick Buchanan right now being welcomed by a throng of supporters.

utterances.speaker: PATRICK BUCHANAN, FORMER REPUBLICAN PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
utterances.sentences: Did I not tell you we would make history?

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: In 1992, a dark horse Republican ran for president on a then controversial slogan.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: America first. America first. America first.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: America first. His name was Pat Buchanan. And he shocked the pundits with a surprisingly strong showing in the New Hampshire primary.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The president of the United States.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: He scared the sitting president, George H.W. Bush. Buchanan would eventually fail but he was the canary in the America first coalmine.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Maintaining your sovereignty of your own country.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Why did his America first message fall short then, and yet become a massive success years later?This is the story.

utterances.speaker: REAGAN
utterances.sentences: We were with you then, we are with you now.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Of how the party of Ronald Reagan.CHIEF JUSTICE JOHN ROBERTS, U.S. SUPREME COURT: So help me, God. DONALD TRUMP, U.S. PRESIDENT-ELECT: So help me, God.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Became the party of Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: From this day forward, it's going to be only America first. America first.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Before Trump --

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Looking at here, you can't tell him Republicans from the Democrats or independents out here.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: -- there was Pitchfork Pat Buchanan. A former staffer with President Nixon turned conservative cable star.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Crossfire. On the right, Pat Buchanan.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Buchanan long had the pulse of the GOP's base.

utterances.speaker: REAGAN
utterances.sentences: We've been together eight years now. And soon, it'll be time for me to go.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And with Reagan's departure and communism's defeat.

utterances.speaker: REAGAN
utterances.sentences: Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: I'm ready to roll. Good to see you again. ZAKARIAisolationists tradition. His rival for the soul of the GOP was Reagan's successor, George Herbert Walker Bush. Bush was the quintessential establishment Republican, determined that America should continue to lead the world after the fall of the Berlin wall. He helped reunified Germany. GEORGE H.W. BUSH, 41ST PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: Germany is united. Germany is free. Tonight, the battle has been joined.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And he led an international coalition to kick Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The skies over Baghdad have been illuminated.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: That victory was swift and convincing.H.W. BUSH: Kuwait is liberated.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Bush declared a new world order, led by the USA.H.W. BUSH: A new world order where diverse nations are drawn together in common cause.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The economy today.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The economy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The economy.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But across the nation, many Americans did not feel they were winning.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Unemployment is the highest in nearly a decade.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The country was in a recession. With the Cold War won, people wanted to focus on problems at home. From his perch on cable television, Pat Buchanan took notice. And Pitchfork Pat seized this moment.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Declaring my candidacy for the Republican nomination for president of the United States.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Reagan had spoken of America as a city on a hill. Buchanan saw a fortress in need of defense.H.W. BUSH: The United States and Mexican governments.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Buchanan blasted free trade deals.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: The president ought to be tougher in protecting American jobs and American businesses and American industries.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: He rejected international commitments, demanded a border wall, and he summed it all up with one big slogan.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: I believe in a foreign policy of American First.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Buchanan's America First stance translates into opposition to foreign aid, lower taxes, trade protectionism, and immigration restrictions.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: To the shock of the political establishment, his message resonated.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Patrick Buchanan right now being welcomed by a throng of supporters.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: He earned nearly 40 percent of the vote in New Hampshire.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Did I not tell you we would make history?

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Bush would win the nomination easily. But Buchanan would eventually win the argument for the party's future.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: My friends, we must take back our cities and take back our culture, and take back our country.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: In 1996, Buchanan won the New Hampshire primary.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: A Buchanan bombshell rocks the Granite State.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: That was Pat Buchanan's high watermark. But his America First philosophy had an impact on the GOP.GEORGE W. BUSH, 43RD PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We will not be permanent peacekeepers, dividing warring parties.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: In 2000 during George W. Bush's presidential campaign he said America should scale back its foreign commitments.W. BUSH: I don't think our troops ought to be used for what's called nation-building.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Then suddenly the word changed. After the attacks on September 11th, Bush promised to eliminate terrorist threats around the world.W. BUSH: The people who knocked these buildings down will hear all of us soon. The United States Military has begun strikes against Al-Qaeda terrorists training camps. ZAKARIA: He invaded Afghanistan. W. BUSH: Coalition forces have begun striking selected targets.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: And then Iraq.W. BUSH: All who live in tyranny and hopelessness, the United States will not ignore your oppression.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A totally transformed Bush said he would spread freedom and democracy everywhere.W. BUSH: When you stand for your liberty, we will stand with you.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But the wars dragged on inconclusively and thousands of Americans were killed and wounded in far-off places.

utterances.speaker: SUSAN LISOVICZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: The U.S. banking system remains in deep trouble.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Then in 2008, the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression shattered the economy. Once again America's elites looked like they had led the country astray. Along came the Tea party, a hard right rebellion against those elites. Its big target was Bush's successor, Barack Obama, America's first black president.But the wars and financial crisis had happened on Bush's watch. W. BUSH: I'm going to sign it into law.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: A rage-filled right-wing base went after the Republican establishment as much as the Democrats. They believe that as the country navigated a globalizing world, they were being left behind. America First became an alluring reframe and Donald Trump became the ideal messenger.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: They're bringing drugs, they're bringing crime, they're rapists, and some, I assume, are good people.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Donald Trump has often been accused of having no real convictions.

utterances.speaker: BUCHANAN
utterances.sentences: Do you have an interest in political office at the national level?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Well, I'll tell you, Pat, they treated me beautifully in New Hampshire.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: But he had been preaching his version of America First for decades.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I'd make our allies pay their fair share.

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: Trump slapped tariffs on trusted allies and tore up treaties.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The United States will withdraw. REAGAN

utterances.speaker: ZAKARIA
utterances.sentences: The party of Reagan had been transformed into the party of Trump.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Witch hunt, witch hunt, scam, hoax.
